profileText: A Delegate from Georgia; born in Waynesboro, Ga., August 31, 1744; attended the common schools; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Savannah, Ga.; one of the four originators of the ``Sons of Liberty''; delegate to the Provincial Congress of Georgia in 1775; Member of the Continental Congress in 1775; member of the executive council in 1777; Governor of Georgia in 1778 and 1784; member of the commission to establish the boundary line between Georgia and South Carolina; chief justice of Georgia in 1786; unsuccessful candidate for Governor in 1787; justice for Chatham County in 1787; mayor of Savannah in 1789 and 1790; judge of the State superior court in 1792; died at ``White Bluff,'' near Savannah, Ga., July 20, 1796.

researchRecord.name: In the Archibald Bulloch Papers, 1769-1777, 13 items.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include John Houstoun. A finding aid for the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Stephen Drayton Papers, 1773, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A photocopy of a letter from Stephen Drayton to John Houstoun written on March 20, 1773. Stephen Drayton discusses trouble with Button Gwinnett over the purchase of land.

researchRecord.name: 1773, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Houstoun to an unidentified recipient written on December 14, 1773. John Houstoun gives the recipient advice concerning a mortgage.

researchRecord.name: In Washington Irving's Life of Washington, Volumes III and XII, ca. 1756-1838.
In the Henry Laurens Papers, 1779, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Henry Laurens to John Houston written on December 16, 1779. Henry Laurens reports a victory of the French and Spanish fleets over a British squadron under Sir Charles Hardy, encourages Georgia to send some able representatives to Congress, and forwards a letter (not present) to Governor John Houstoun.

researchRecord.name: 1773-1793, 18 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include an order for the defense of Richmond County, a letter dated 1784 from John Habersham discussing negotiations with Indian representatives concerning land purchases and an incident between Georgia residents and Indians, a statement of dissent from the Boundary Commission concerning the boundary dispute between South Carolina and Georgia; a petition to adjourn court to allow jurors to put down an Indian attack; and miscellaneous land grants, indentures, and summonses.
